content: All software has bugs. Every time a new version of

tag: html body text p a span
html body text p span
content: is released,no matter how thoroughly tested, bug reports arrive after the fact. Wedocument Kermit 95 bugs in several places:

tag: html body text dl dt a span
html body text dl dt span

content: Known bugs (most of them fixed, or with workarounds provided) at the time ofthe most recent release (HTML).

tag: html body text dl dt a span
html body text dl dt span
html body text dl dd span
content: Bugs discovered or reported since the most recent release, often withworkarounds (plain text).

tag: html body text dl dt a span

content: Commonly reported problems are addressed here.

tag: html body text p span
content: Kermit 95 was written over a period of years by members of the KermitProject at Columbia University. It is essentially

tag: html body text p a span
html body text p span
content: with Windows-specific code layered on top(notably the terminal emulator and the GUI features) and underneath (Windowsfile, device, and networking interfaces). Due to diminished revenues afterthe economic decline of 2000-2001, Jeffrey Altman, the author of theWindows-specific code (as well as of the security code � SSH, SSL/TLS,Kerberos, and SRP � and much else) was laid off and now has his owncompany,

tag: html body text p a span
html body text p span
content: . All our Windows development expertise is now at that company.Jeff continues to work on Kermit 95, and has produced numerous fixes andenhancements, listed here:

tag: html body text blockquote a span
html body text p span
content: Since Jeff is no longer paid by Columbia to do this work, his updates are notavailable from the Kermit Project. If you need any of the updates listedin the document just referenced, you can get them directly from Jeff underthe terms listed here:

tag: html body text blockquote a span
html body text p span
content: Similarly, those who need new features added or custom modifications madeto Kermit 95 should contact Jeff directly.

tag: html body text p span
html body text p i span
html body text p span
content: (questions, troubleshooting, etc) is provided bythe Kermit Project as outlined in the below, except that when a probleminvolves certain facets of the program (such as terminal emulation orsecurity) it might be necessary to refer the case to Secure Endpoints.

tag: html body text p span
content: We do expect to have a

tag: html body text p a b span

tag: html body text p b span

content: , if it comes, will be only for Windows XP andlater, will be fully checked out on Windows Vista, and will appear only inGUI (not Console) form. It will come with a modern MSI installer (allowingautomated installation and upgrades via Group Policy andorganization-specific customizations, e.g. packaging of custom Dialerentries, initialization files, and scripts). And since we won't besupporting Windows 95/98/ME any more, we should be able to put the Dialerback to using the convenient notebook tabs for its entries rather than thecurrent awkward "direct access" one-at-a-time method. We also expect thatthe next release of Kermit 95 will support large files (transfer, access,and management of files bigger than 2GB) and 64-bit integer arithmetic, andperhaps also a GUI dialog for file uploads.More about the next release

tag: html body text b a span

content: An organization (university, company, government agency) that provides Kermitsoftware to its computer users or clients should also provide technicalsupport to them. The organization may appoint a technical liaison with theKermit Project, and we will be glad to supply support to that person.

tag: html body text p span
html body text p i span
html body text p span
content: send all of its users to us for technicalsupport. This can not possibly work, since (a) we do not understand thehardware, software, communications, and networking setup of your organization;(b) we do not know what customizations have been made to Kermit at yourorganization, and (c) we do not have the resources to help large masses ofpeople one-on-one.

tag: html body text p span
content: If you are member of an organization that provided you with Kermit software,please obtain support from within your own organization. If they can't helpyou, then have your organization's technical liaison contact us. This allowsthe necessary information to reach your entire organization at once, ratherthan one person at a time. If your organization does not have a liaison withus, then they should appoint one.

tag: html body text b a span
content: HINTS FOR PREPARING A PROBLEM REPORT

tag: html body text div i span
content: . . . which might help yousolve the problem yourself

tag: html body text p span
content: Many people are not aware that there are hundreds of different Kermit programson thousands of different hardware and software platforms, operating over allkinds of different connections. Not everybody is using the same Kermitsoftware you are, on the same kind of computer, or over the same kind ofconnection. Before we can begin to help you, we need the following preliminaryinformation:

tag: html body text ol li b span
content: Is your question about Kermit software?

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: If it is a question about email or some other application, even if youare accessing it

tag: html body text ol li ol li i span
html body text ol li ol li span
content: Kermit, then it probably is not a questionabout Kermit software itself. The Kermit help desk does not offer help withemail programs or other non-Kermit applications, except to the extent thatwe can advise you choose the appropriate terminal emulation and help you setup the key mappings, if necessary. Otherwise, you will need to ask theowners, makers, or vendors of the non-Kermit application, or yourorganization's or ISP's local help desk, for help or instruction.

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: A lot of third-party software packages include a Kermit file-transferprotocol implementation (usually not a very good one). If your software isnot a Kermit software program from the Kermit Project at ColumbiaUniversity, it is not our software and we can't help you with it. Kermitprograms all have "Kermit" in their names, like MS-DOS Kermit, Kermit 95,C-Kermit, G-Kermit, Kermit-370, etc. If you are asking about the Kermitimplementation in somebody else's software, you'll need to go to the makeror vendor of that software for help or instruction.

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: If you have a problem transferring files with Kermit protocol between aKermit Project program and a third-party product, we'll support our end of it.If the problem lies with the non-Columbia implementation, we'll do our best toprovide a diagnosis or workaround, but we can not be expected to support orsanction improper or buggy Kermit protocol implementations in third-partyproducts.

tag: html body text ol li p span
content: If there is a problem with the interface between some other vendor's softwareand one of our Kermit programs, have the vendor of that software get in touchwith us.

tag: html body text ol li b span
content: Which Kermit program are you using?

tag: html body text ol li span
content: (What is its name? How does itidentify itself when you start it?) The most commonly used Kermit programs

content: of the Kermit program? (Most Kermitprograms have a "version" command; if not, the version number isannounced when Kermit starts). If you are using an old version(see

content: ), we willgenerally recommend that you install the current version and see if theproblem still occurs. A list of current Kermit software versions can be found

content: If it is Kermit 95 2.0 or later, are you using the GUI version orConsole version?

tag: html body text ol li span
content: This information is especially important if your reportconcerns screen appearance, character sets, fonts, etc. At this point,everybody should be using the version 2.1.3 of K95 in its

tag: html body text ol li a span
html body text ol li span
content: . There is no reason to use the Consoleversion (which suffers from countless bugs and restrictions in Windowsconsole application support) unless you really know what you are doing.

content: , did you build it from source code,or are you using one of the prebuilt binaries? If you are using a prebuiltbinary, which one? Are you sure it is the appropriate one for your computer?(To overcome such problems as library version mismatches, you might want todownload and build from source.) If you built C-Kermit from source code,which makefile target did you use?

content: are you using (or are you trying to make)?Direct serial, dialup, Telnet, SSH, Rlogin, X.25, ...?

tag: html body text ol li b span
html body text ol li ol li b span
content: Which communication device are you using

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: ? Some operating systemshave a selection of drivers for the same device, which are selected by usingdifferent names for the device; see, for example, the discussion of serialport names in HP-UX in the

tag: html body text ol li ol li a span
html body text ol li ol li span
html body text ol li ol li blockquote i span

html body text ol li ol li blockquote i span
content: , you should be aware that it has

tag: html body text ol li ol li blockquote i b span
html body text ol li ol li blockquote i span
content: for accessing serial ports and modems; the traditional, built-in"DOS" method ("set port com1, set modem type usrobotics, ...") and theWindows-specific Control Panel interface ("set port tapi"). If one doesn'twork, try the other. See the

tag: html body text ol li ol li blockquote i a span
html body text ol li ol li blockquote i span
html body text ol li ol li b span
content: What kind of modem are you using?

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: Is it internal or external? Ifyou have a PC with an internal modem, is it a real modem or a "Winmodem"? Ifyou think it might be a Winmodem,

tag: html body text ol li ol li a span
html body text ol li ol li span
html body text ol li ol li b span
content: What kind of modem does Kermit

tag: html body text ol li ol li b i span
html body text ol li ol li b span
html body text ol li ol li span
content: In otherwords, has Kermit been informed appropriately as to your modem type?

tag: html body text ol li ol li b span
content: What are the serial port communications parameters

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: : speed, parity,flow control? In most Kermit programs, these are listed by the SHOWCOMMUNICATIONS command.

tag: html body text ol li ol li b span
content: What kind of modem is on the other end?

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: What is the remote modemconnected to? � A serial port on the computer, a terminal server?

tag: html body text ol li ol li b span
content: What other communications equipment is involved?

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: � An X.25PAD? A 3270 protocol converter? A terminal server? An intermediatecomputer? etc etc...

tag: html body text ol li ol li blockquote i span
content: A serial connection (direct or dialup) must have an

tag: html body text ol li ol li blockquote i b span
html body text ol li ol li blockquote i span
content: at every junction between computer (or terminal server, etc)and modem. This means that each pair of devices that are connected must beusing the

tag: html body text ol li ol li blockquote i b span
html body text ol li ol li blockquote i span
content: kind of flow control, usually either RTS/CTS (hardware)or Xon/Xoff (software). If this is not true, there can be any amount of dataloss or corruption on the connection.

tag: html body text ol li ol li b span
content: If your complaint is that you see garbage when the connection ismade...

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: please describe the garbage: is it 100% garbage?Or is some of the text recognizable?

tag: html body text ol li ol li ul li span
content: If approximately 50% of the charactersare wrong, you probably need to tell Kermit to "set parity even" (or otherparity choice)

tag: html body text ol li ol li ul li span
content: If all of the characters are wrong, there is almost certainly a speedmismatch between

tag: html body text ol li ol li ul li i span
html body text ol li ol li ul li span
html body text ol li ol li ul li i span
html body text ol li ol li ul li span
content: the answeringmodem's serial port and the serial port of the computer or device it isconnected to.

tag: html body text ol li ol li b span
content: How did you make the connection?

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: � Did you use Kermit's built-inDIAL command? If not, please try it ("help dial" for more information). TheDIAL command automatically does what it can to synchronize serial-port speed,flow control, and other critical parameters between your computer and thedialing modem.

tag: html body text ol li p span
html body text ol li p b span
html body text ol li p span
html body text ol li ol li span
content: Are you sure you have the appropriate kind of cable (e.g. null-modeminstead of modem)?

tag: html body text ol li ol li b a span
html body text ol li ol li b span
html body text ol li ol li span
content: Have you correctly identified the communication port to Kermit(e.g. COM1 or COM2 or a TAPI device name in K95; /dev/ttyS0 or somesuchin Linux/Unix, etc)? (SET PORT or SET LINE).

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: Is the speed ("baud") the same on both ends? For example, if the speedis 9600 bps ("baud") on the far end, then Kermit's speed must also beset to 9600 (SET SPEED). A typical symptom of a speed mismatch is that yousee characters on your screen but they are total nonsense.

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: If the computer on the far end uses "parity", you have to set Kermit'sparity to match: SET PARITY EVEN, ODD, or MARK. A typical symptom of aparity mismatch is that some characters are intelligible, some are not.

tag: html body text ol li ol li span
content: If the terminal screen is completely frozen, you might have aflow-control deadlock, often caused by an

tag: html body text ol li ol li a span
html body text ol li ol li span
content: or bytransmission noise. Tell Kermit to SET FLOW NONE, and if that unsticks thescreen, then you can come back later and fix the real problem.

tag: html body text ol li b span
content: What kind of computer or device or service is on the other end

tag: html body text ol li span
html body text ol li blockquote i span
content: Is the device, host, or service text based? Is it a PPP server? Do you haveto log in to it? Do you get a login prompt? Do you get a menu? Are youimmediately connected to a Kermit server?

tag: html body text ol li b span
html body text ol li span
html body text ol li span
html body text ol li b span
html body text ol li span
content: : what Kermit programand version is on the other computer? Does the transfer fail at the verybeginning (constant retrying of the first packet), or partway through? Doesit happen the same way every time? NOTE: Most current releases of Kermitsoftware do not support transfer of files larger than 2GB;

tag: html body text ol li a span
html body text ol li span
html body text ol li span
html body text ol li b span
html body text ol li span

tag: html body text ol li a span
html body text ol li span
content: .If you are having problems with F keys, Arrow keys, the Numeric keypad,or the Backspace key, consult the appropriate items in the

content: What is the exact nature of the problem?

tag: html body text ol li span
content: Is it a failure to makea connection? A failure to transfer files? A problem with terminal emulation?Exactly what happens, compared to what you think should happen?

tag: html body text ol li b span
html body text ol li span

content: If you are using email to follow up on a previous or ongoing matter, pleaseinclude relevant portions of previous correspondence. If you want to

tag: html body text p b span

content: . Virus scanners will removethem. Anyway, since Kermit scripts and logs are plain text, you can justinclude them directly in your message, there is no need to structure them asattachments.

tag: html body text p span
content: Data communication is rarely as simple as we'd like it to be. From thevery basic set of questions above, you can see that there are at leastthree, and perhaps as many as eight (or more) completely separate hardwareand software components to your connection, all of which must be configuredto interoperate with each other and to pass the desired data through.

tag: html body text p span
content: This is why communications software can be harder to use than self-containedapplications that stay inside your computer, where (hopefully) allquantities are known. Also note that when you are using Kermit to make aserial connection, you are performing the job of a network specialist� making a connection that did not exist before, probably using avariety of equipment and software from different makers. Networkspecialists need years of training before they can do this � don'texpect it to be effortless, although sometimes it might be. Every case isdifferent. (Network connections are usually easier, because networkspecialists have already set up the network for you.)

tag: html body text p span
content: Kermit manuals are generally 400-700 pages long. A great many of these pagesare devoted to the many and varied communication methods, and what that can gowrong on each one, and methods for diagnosis and repair of problems. Pleaseuse the manuals. If you have suggestions for making them better,

tag: html body text p a span
html body text p span
html body text p span
content: Thank you for helping us to serve you better!
